Key Arguments: The bill lacks consideration for freedom of speech and poses fundamental flaws.
It divides society into two classes, disproportionately harming ordinary citizens.
Excessive fines and broad application of the code restrict speech more than necessary.
Judging truth is difficult as expert consensus can change over time.
The bill's scope unintentionally affects smaller websites and foreign entities.
Delegating legislative power to private entities raises constitutional concerns.
Notable Quotes: I am, to be direct, absolutely incensed by this bill, but will do my best to respond constructively.
The internet has been an invaluable tool for empowering regular people, and this bill absolutely risks undermining their freedom of speech.
Accurately judging what is objectively true or false is an impossible task, as new information is constantly being discovered.
It is impractical and unrealistic to expect digital services from all around the world to comply with Australian laws.
